Gloriana_(band):
{{short description|American country music band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Gloriana | image = Gloriana band.jpg | caption = Gloriana at [[Walmart Soundcheck]], August 2012. L-R: Rachel Reinert, Tom Gossin, Mike Gossin | alt = Country music band Gloriana performing in concert. | landscape = yes | image_size = | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 2008–2017 | label = {{Plainlist| * Emblem * [[Reprise Records|Reprise Nashville]] * [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]] }} | website = {{URL|http://www.gloriana.com}} | past_members = {{Plainlist| * [[Cheyenne Kimball]] * [[Rachel Reinert]] * Mike Gossin * Tom Gossin }} }} '''Gloriana''' was an American [[country music]] group founded in 2008 by [[Cheyenne Kimball]] (vocals, [[mandolin]]), [[Rachel Reinert]] (vocals), and brothers Tom Gossin (vocals, guitar) and Mike Gossin (vocals, guitar). Prior to the group's foundation, Kimball recorded as a solo artist. The original lineup recorded one [[Gloriana (album)|self-titled album]] for Emblem/[[Reprise Records]] in 2009, which included their first chart hit, "[[Wild at Heart (Gloriana song)|Wild at Heart]]". Kimball left before the release of the band's second album ''[[A Thousand Miles Left Behind]]'', which produced their highest-charting single, "[[(Kissed You) Good Night]]", along with the top 20 "[[Can't Shake You]]". After a third album, ''[[Three (Gloriana album)|Three]]'', Reinert left as well, effectively disbanding the group. ==History== Brothers Tom and Mike Gossin were born in [[Utica, New York]]. They both took [[classical piano]] lessons from age 5. At 10, Tom began studying jazz with a local [[jazz music|jazz]] musician and at 12, he began to play the guitar. Tom, along with third Gossin brother Stephen, founded their own band "Oblique" in high school. Stephen and Tom later moved to [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] together, where they attended [[University of North Carolina at Wilmington]], with Tom majoring in guitar. After a professor suggested that he pursue songwriting and performing, Tom dropped out of the university and started playing music and selling independent records at gigs he played. Mike learned drums at age 8 and, like Tom, started playing guitar at 12. He moved to Wilmington after high school to join Tom there. He joined a group with Tom and Stephen during which time they filmed a reality series that did not last long. Tom and Mike moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where they began performing as a duo.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gloriana/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307034708/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/gloriana/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 7, 2009|title=Gloriana biography|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=2009-04-07}}{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1110916/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Gloriana biography|last=Leggett|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=2009-06-15}} [[Rachel Reinert]] was born in [[Sarasota, Florida]], and lived in [[Marietta, Georgia]] before moving to [[Santa Ana, California]] with her family at age 6. She attended the [[Orange County School of the Arts]], a charter performing arts school, where she studied musical theatre from 7th to 10th grade. She started playing the guitar and turning her poetry into songs at age 14. With a teacher's help, she began recording [[demo (music)|demos]], and was signed to a publishing deal out of Nashville at age 15. She graduated high school through independent study and moved to Nashville when she turned 16, and was working on her songwriting skills when she met the Gossins, who found her through her [[MySpace]] page. The group's fourth and final member, [[Cheyenne Kimball]], was born in [[Jacksonville, North Carolina]] but raised in [[Frisco, Texas]]. A performer by age 10, she entered the television talent show ''[[America's Most Talented Kid]]'', and won the show's top honor at age 12. One year after her win, Kimball recorded a solo album on [[Epic Records]]. This album included songs that she had written with [[John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]], whom she met after a trip to Nashville. When Cheyenne was in her late teens she had a reality show on MTV that lasted one season. She joined the Gossin brothers and Reinert after meeting them in a nightclub, and the four members began writing songs and performing together. ===2008–2010: ''Gloriana''=== [[File:US_Navy_101105-N-7524O-001_Cheyenne_Kimball,_a_performer_with_the_country_music_band,_Gloriana,_performs_in_the_hangar_bay_of_the_aircraft_carrier.jpg|thumb|left|[[Cheyenne Kimball]], pictured here in 2010, was a vocalist and mandolinist in the group for their first album.|alt=Musician Cheyenne Kimball playing a mandolin.]] Once the four members of Gloriana were in place, they began recording demos, and sent one to Emblem Records, a label owned by [[Matt Serletic]], a [[record producer]] who has worked with [[Matchbox 20]]. The four members worked with Serletic, and Nashville songwriters such as [[Jeffrey Steele]], [[Brett James]] and [[Wayne Kirkpatrick]], among others. By February the group had signed with the label but had not yet come up with a name. In early 2009, the group released its debut single "[[Wild at Heart (Gloriana song)|Wild at Heart]]", which Serletic wrote with [[Josh Kear]] and [[Stephanie Bentley]], another former Epic artist.{{cite web |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2009/01/gloriana/ |title=Gloriana |access-date=2009-01-26 |last=Ross |first=David M. |date=2009-01-14 |work=Music Row}} It became the highest-selling country music debut single of 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=3116|title=Gloriana debut available for listening today|date=2009-07-29|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=2009-08-01}} The group also signed to [[Taylor Swift]]'s 2009-2010 [[Fearless tour]]. In May 2009, Gloriana released a four-song digital [[extended play|EP]], comprising "Wild at Heart" and three other songs from the album. On August 4, 2009, the band released its [[Gloriana (album)|self-titled]] debut, which peaked at No. 2 on [[Top Country Albums]] and No. 3 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], shortly before "Wild at Heart" peaked at No. 15. The album's second single, "[[How Far Do You Wanna Go?]]", was released in September. The band won the [[American Music Award]]'s Breakthrough Artist of the Year in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2009/12/21/gloriana-attributes-breakthrough-to-fans/|title=Gloriana attributes breakthrough to fans|last=Roland|first=Tom|date=2009-12-21|work=[[Great American Country]]|access-date=2010-01-27}} It was announced on March 16, 2010 that the group had won the 2010 Academy of Country Music's Top New Vocal Group award. On August 18, 2010, "Wild at Heart" was certified Gold by the RIAA. A third single, "[[The World Is Ours Tonight]]," debuted in early 2010. It was included on a March 2010 reissue of the band's debut album. ===2011–2013: ''A Thousand Miles Left Behind''=== In early 2011, the group announced the release of a new single, "[[Wanna Take You Home]]", which acted as the lead-off single to their second studio album, ''[[A Thousand Miles Left Behind]]''. "Wanna Take You Home" was released to country radio on 28 March 2011,{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|publisher=All Access|access-date=February 23, 2011}} and went on to become the group's fourth Top 40 hit. On 11 July 2011, Gloriana announced the departure of Cheyenne Kimball.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/gloriana-s-cheyenne-kimball-exits-band |title=Gloriana's Cheyenne Kimball Exits Band |magazine=[[Country Weekly]] |access-date=July 11, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714055602/http://www.countryweekly.com/news/gloriana-s-cheyenne-kimball-exits-band |archive-date=July 14, 2011 }} The band found out about Kimball's plan to leave via Twitter. They continued working on their second album without Kimball,Giles, Jeff. "Gloriana Describes the 'Evolving Process' Behind Their New Album, 'A Thousand Miles Left Behind'." CMT. September 25, 2011. Web. Retrieved 2012-04-18 although she still appears in the "Wanna Take You Home" music video. The song's music video, directed by [[TK McKamy]], was shot over the course of several days at a private residence outside of Nashville. On October 4, 2011, Gloriana released their second single from the album, "[[(Kissed You) Good Night]]," on their official website.{{cite web|url=http://www.gloriana.com/news/501a2c-our-new-single-is/|title=(Kissed You) Good Night|publisher=All Access|access-date=October 4, 2011}} On 13 January 2012, the music video for "(Kissed You) Good Night" premiered on [[Freeform (TV channel)|ABC Family]].Gloriana. "'[http://www.gloriana.com/news/kissed-you-good-night-first-look/ (Kissed You) Good Night' First Look!]" Gloriana. Retrieved: 2012-04-18. On May 20, 2012, the band performed their single "(Kissed You) Good Night" on the television show ''[[The Bachelorette (American TV series)|The Bachelorette]]''. On 31 July 2012, the album was released On September 10, 2012, the album's third single, "[[Can't Shake You]]", was released. The single was featured on the season 2 finale of [[The CW]]'s [[Hart of Dixie]] with the band guest starring as themselves. ===2014–2017: ''Three''=== The group released a new single, "Best Night Ever," in February 2014, and it went on to be a minor Top 40 hit on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart. It was followed later in the year by "[[Trouble (Gloriana song)|Trouble]]," which reached a peak of number 24 on the ''Billboard'' Country Airplay chart and served as the lead-off single to Gloriana's third studio album, ''[[Three (Gloriana album)|Three]]'', which was released on June 2, 2015. The album produced no other singles, and in January 2016, Reinert announced her departure from the band.{{cite web|author=Billy Dukes |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/rachel-reinert-leaves-gloriana/ |title=Rachel Reinert Leaves Gloriana |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=7 January 2016 |access-date=2020-04-24}} Tom Gossin began touring as a solo artist in 2017.{{cite web |author=Shannon McCabe |url=http://www.encorepub.com/long-road-home-singer-songwriter-tom-gossin-puts-down-roots-in-wilmington/ |title=LONG ROAD HOME: Singer-songwriter Tom Gossin puts down roots in Wilmington – ILM's Alternative Weekly Voice |website=Encorepub.com |date=2017-04-04 |access-date=2020-04-24 |archive-date=2017-11-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114042338/http://www.encorepub.com/long-road-home-singer-songwriter-tom-gossin-puts-down-roots-in-wilmington/ |url-status=dead }} In mid-2018, Reinert released the solo single "Cool".{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/rachel-reinert-cool-interview/|title=HEAR FORMER GLORIANA SINGER RACHEL REINERT'S FIRST SOLO EFFORT, 'COOL' [EXCLUSIVE PREMIERE]|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=July 25, 2018|work=Taste of Country|access-date=July 28, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:20em;"| Details ! colspan="3"| Peak positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:9em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:45px;"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
